media.caption: We lose small things almost daily, whether it be because we toss and forget about them or because we view them as trash or something disposable.
media.credit: Idaho Public Archaeology, Objects: (bottom left) 1241, (top left) 23-01751, (bottom middle) 1095, (bottom right) 23-01617, (top right) 1211

text.headline: lost and broken things: what we leave behind at MHS, Part 2
text.text: Follow other characters as they navigate a school day and lunchtime.

media.caption: A large number of high school students eating lunch in and around MHS is bound to result in tons of food wrappers, plastic utensils, and more left on the ground.
media.credit: Idaho Public Archaeology, Objects: (far left) 10, (top middle) 1039, (bottom middle) 1227, (far right) 108

text.headline: 2004-lunchtime Games
text.text:
The lunch bell rings through the cavernous, fluorescent hallways of MHS. The chatter of hungry students fills the air as they rush from classrooms to vending machines and grab snack-like lunches. 

You run out of the bathroom, swinging your backpack over one shoulder and rushing to where your friends wait for you every day. Turning the corner, your three friends wave at you and you fall into step with them. You all rush towards the doors at the center of the school which open up into the courtyard; a raggedy old volleyball court adorns the center of the courtyard that you all rush right over to get to the picnic tables before they’re overrun by competing friend groups.

media.caption: What drinks and snacks were in your school or office's vending machine?

text.headline: 2004-lunchtime Games
text.text:
Two of your friends launch themselves at the table, laughing loudly as a couple of kids who were also going towards it had to turn around and stomp away to a patch of grass. You chuckle and salute the others kindheartedly, plopping your backpack down on the table, feeding into the victory. As you sit, you pull a plastic soda bottle out of the bottle holder on the side of your bag. You unscrew the cap and take a sip, then pass it around to your friends. “Anyone want some?” 

Two of your friends shake their heads, one saying, “We made a vending machine stop too,” holding up their bottles. But your third friend nods enthusiastically and takes your offer. “Man, I needed some sugar,” she says, laughing and laying her head on the table.

media.caption: Perhaps one of the pennies thrown in this game is the same 1950 wheat penny lost by our character in Part 1. Lost things have a way of resurfacing!

text.headline: 2004-lunchtime games
text.text: She doesn’t get to rest long. You sneak a coin out of your jeans pocket, the penny shining in the midday sunlight, and fling it at her. She yelps and stands up. You’re about to apologize, but as you’re catching your breath from laughter, she throws something from her own pocket and it hits you square in the forehead. For the next few minutes, your friend group erupts into a forgotten lunch and an intense penny game, copper coins flinging through the air and landing on faces, arms, and knees.

media.caption: Through this penny game, a 1980 coin finds itself lost and forgotten on the grounds of MHS.

text.headline: 2004-lunchtime games
text.text: Luckily no bruises are acquired today, but finally exhausted, you surrender by waving your white paper napkin flimsily in the air. You finally munch into your PB&J sandwich, your friends all watching you closely to make sure you’re not faking them out before laughing heartily and joining you to finally eat and fuel up for the rest of the school day. No one thinks to pick up the tossed pennies, and the grass slowly grows over and around them until daily footsteps by fellow students stomp them into the dirt.

media.caption: Take a look at these lost and broken things. What of yours will be found by archaeologists in the future?

text.headline: over a lifetime
text.text: Think about every little thing you lose and break throughout a lifetime. Just one city block (such as the one MHS takes up) can hold a myriad of items that, once upon a time, someone held dear. Or, items that were used only to end up broken and tossed aside to make way for something new and improved. As these lost and broken things pile up, they tell us a lot about the humans who owned and used them, including ourselves.
